segments.text: Where were we?
Oh, the trees.
And I said, well, I think it's $50 million, but I'll check on it.
And I came back with a precise figure of the Forest Service right upstairs.
And he said, I thought of all those millions of trees that we plant through the 4-H and FFA and commercially.
He said, then I had just signed the...
authorization to buy the, oh, I think it was 300 live oaks that were placed around the perimeter where we thought we were going to lose the big oaks, the dying of the live oak decline.
And he said, here's the letter I proposed.
Dear brother so-and-so, we plant more than we cut.
And I think it's only fair to know that the enclosed letter was written by someone, and they signed your name at the bottom.
Sincerely, Jack K. Williams.
Here are some little things that I took notes on about him.
On being president, I have had from friends notes of commiseration on my promotion, various expressions written and verbal
which range in emotional scale from condolences to abject pity.
He said, this job should be filled by a friendless orphan, a bachelor, one skilled in tightrope walking and bronco busting.
And then on another occasion, the atmosphere of education is heady with the smell of change for some, perfume for others, brimstone.
on campus riots, what would happen, Dr. Williams, if we had a riot?
Police and strength will be called without hesitation.
Those identified as leaders of felonious conduct and as inciters of a riot will be moved off campus, and the injunctive process will be applied to prevent their reentry.
On former students, he counted among A&M's assets the legion of former students
where fierce loyalty to this university is no less material than it is vocal.
This being a formal way of saying that Aggie alumni put their dollars where their mouths are.
And here are just some notes about him.
He was a strong supporter of the Corps and that very few people knew of his experiences in the Marines and the Pacific Theater during the war.
And he had a very positive attitude about the military.
Had a marvelous influence on bringing new faculty of eminence and obtaining the funding to keep them.
And he had the very innovative idea of using students in presentations at budget hearings.
And that really was a step forward for us.
Had a strong impact on grants and gifts from industry and endowed professorships.
some of the significant accomplishments under him, the Sea Grant designation, and I had bringing Frank Wardlaw to plan and develop the A&M Press.
His pet peeve was federal intervention in higher education, probes, reports, investigations, audits, surveys, visitation, and he referred to all of that as the web of entanglement.
His personality, I mentioned they marched on the president's home when he came in and the resulting $5,000 grant from the Strait Foundation.
You remember they came in and they marched on his home and welcomed him and that really struck him.
He was warmly down to earth.
One time holding and handing up fluorescent bulbs to a man on the ladder at his home.
He told me one time, he said, Cooper, your hair is getting too long.
He says, I'm going to
If you let it get any longer, I'm going to hold you by the shoulders and let Dooley Bell cut your hair with his clippers.
He loved to visit with elderly folks, and he milked them for their wisdom.
One of the times he fussed at me, we decided to have student leaders at his house and at my house for meals.
And he himself mixed up hamburger meat with onions and mustard and made hamburgers for the kids.
And I had funding from the alumni where I could do things like that and let Randy Matson pay for it.
So when they came to my house the next month, I had little sirloin strip steaks.
And he was mad.
And he came up to me and says, Cooper, he said, they come to the president's home and get hamburgers, and they come to his assistant's home and get sirloin strips.
I says, how's this going to look?

had a note he can be temperamental I mentioned the admissions incident and I mentioned the University of Hill comment about the two Board of Regents he took me to Fort Riley Kansas with him to inspect the summer ROTC camp big contingency of Aggies there and they they used
dozens and dozens of airplanes to shuttle us from the airport to Fort Riley.
And he was greatly opposed to smoking, especially in confined areas.
It really bothered him.
So we got in this plane, and he and I, they had taken the luggage compartment out of the back end of this little plane, and he and I were squeezed in that luggage space.
The pilot was a hot shot, and he started smoking immediately.
It was one of those hot days with convection currents just knocking the little old plane.
It was sickening.
And I could tell that he was getting uptight.
And finally, he said to the pilot, yelling over four or five other men,
Can't you get this thing up a little bit higher, get a little more altitude on it?
He said, we're really getting bounced around back here.
And this pilot looked back.
He says, hell, man.
He said, we're so far overloaded.
He says, it's a wonder we're up this high.
And he looked at me, and he said, Edwin talked to the colonel.
He says, when this is over, we're going to drive back in a staff car.
We're not getting back on the plane.
And I told you about planning more than we cut.
And someone sent me this hate letter.
and thought you should know that they signed your name to it.
Those were some impressions that I had of him.
And then this little talk was about both Rutter and Williams and what I said to the old group.
As you and I reflect back on things as we knew them in old Army days, there have been some changes which we might personally regret.
But the broad thrust these last 30 years has indeed been forward.
And as one writer said, upon what we remember, nothing is more responsible for the good old days than a bad memory.
And so those were the things that I brought to that Sol Ross group.
As far as you know, what were the factors that caused frustration between him and the board?
What did they disagree about?
He wasn't that open about he would let you know that there had been a terrible argument about something.
But it was real hard to get out of him what the argument was about.
He had another policy after he was so gifted at speaking.
I'd say, well, somebody prominent like, say,
Polly Krueger has called and wants to know if he can have a copy of that speech that you made at the San Antonio Club.
And he said, tell Mr. Krueger that I lost it.
He would never give anybody a copy of his speeches.
Like I asked him a few times for some of those anecdotes, like the brick.
And after he was no longer here, Nelda gave me a copy, but not while he was here.
I know that some of what they fussed about had to do with personnel approvals.
And I can't even give you an example of someone that he either thought should have a job or should not in a high position that the board
I do know that he had a difficult time understanding what their position was in regards to enrollment growth.
I know that there were difficulties about such things as well.
Housing is such a terrible problem.
Should the university add more housing, or should we not compete with a
the free economy, whether or not to build more dormitories.
That was a dispute.
There was, I know, some talk about what admission requirements would be.
I know that Mr. Weisenbaker, for example, always felt that we should just let her go, and that most of the wealthy people like him were C students anyway, and so how could we hold them back?
And I remember I was invited when I was dean of admissions, and I know it had to be in the Williams era.
Yeah, I know it did.
To bring them a report on a Sunday afternoon at one of their meetings on enrollment projections
And I was led to believe possible ways to control enrollment.
And I had a whole battery of ideas on that subject.
I had a slide show all made up and appeared before them.
And before I even started my presentation, one of the board members asked about how admission changes requirements
would affect enrollment.
And that was the last word that I spoke that day.
And I went home terribly frustrated because I worried over getting a nice presentation together and didn't say one damn thing.
Not only that, when I got home, I decided to mix up a good strong bourbon and soda and walk out in the backyard and stare at my tomatoes.
One of my grandsons had gotten a bad-bitten racket and leveled the entire crop.
And there were my tomatoes all over the yard.
And the regents wouldn't listen to me.
So it was frustrating.
But those are the kinds of things that would upset him.
And I think even basic philosophies about the direction the university should be moving
and the kind of faculty that we should be pursuing.
Just nearly everything that came up, they would have somebody on that board.
And Mrs. Williams, the hardness that we have experienced in talking with her since he died,
I think she is convinced, was convinced, that they were just trying to run him off and it killed him.
What do you think his goals were for A&M?
I think that he wanted more quality and less quantity.
And when you talk about students, then you're talking about facilities, too.
And you're talking about faculty, too.
And I know that the medical school, he hoped for a law school.
He wanted us a little broader.
The medical school, I know for sure, was a pet hope.
I feel less about the law school in terms of what his hopes were than I did the medical.
Did he have, as far as you know, any particular strong supporters on the board?
and or strong opponents?
None come to mind either way.
But I got the definite feeling that he would have given most anything not to have to go to their meetings, because somebody there would upset him every time.
In a light moment one day,
He said something about playing golf the afternoon the board meeting ended.
And I said, sir, I have heard you say that you're not a very good golfer, but you seem to play golf every afternoon when the board has just left.
Well, I don't understand.
And he said, when I put that golf ball on that tee, I then have the image there is a certain regent's
posterior there, and when I tee off, I can release a little bit of energy.
The key people that he relied upon, Dr. Byers retired as the chief academic officer, and you were already over there.
How did he come to identify John Calhoun as the vice president of academic affairs?
I don't know.
Because it was a personal search.
There wasn't a committee or anything like that.
I was not privy to any discussion on that subject.
He asked me.
But I know he had.
With all contacts I had with him, he had the highest regards for him and for you.

For Winerdi, I heard a conversation one time that John evidently said, you know what, Winerdi is suggesting that we do on this topic or whatever, and I remember Dr. Williams' response was, well, turn him loose and let him fly, or something like that.
But he had a lot of confidence in that team that was over there.
And then he was the one that selected John Colas.
Which was a tremendous.
Oh, my.
Yeah.
And I don't know how that happened.
He did not consult with or ask advice from me on things like that.
He had his own.
Now, you have to understand.
You have to think that a lot of his contacts in the job that he had in Austin would put him in touch with both academic and student services types of people.
In Austin, he didn't have the close friendship with the kinds of friendships that Mr. Rutter had, but he had been the first commissioner of higher education in the coordinating board.

describe William's method of operation with Austin realities legislature and coordinating board like let's make believe it's a budget hearing day well he he could defend I think better than anyone I ever saw

his request for increases in a given area and was just phenomenal at explaining why that particular school should be moving in that direction as related to its mission, which was written out better than anybody ever saw.
And then he used student presentations there and always made sure those were good, sharp people.
But he knew the legislative process, and he knew how to.
He had his own sources on how someone would act at a given time.
I used to go to the coordinating board meetings.
And frankly, I was appalled at a great deal of the ignorance I saw displayed at those meetings.
And one was a fuss between the old man with a cigar from Plainview and Mr. Weir that we were talking about the other night in Carpus.
And they were fussing about, arguing about whether we needed to approve a medical school at Texas Tech or a law school somewhere else, not the A&M Law School.
And finally, the old man from
from level land and says, well, which do you think is more important, a doctor or a lawyer?
He says, it depends on whether I'm in a hospital or in jail.
I remember that one.
I remember that one.
But that he could work with.
Let's see what that is.
Let me turn this on.
The fact is that dealing with the appointed members of the coordinating board, he could fly circles around those people pretty well.
I think make them feel real ignorant if they didn't do what he thought was right.
I remember a couple of budget hearings when, with a straight face, he would introduce the students that he'd brought
as students that he just happened to encounter as he was leaving the campus.
He knew nothing about them.
They were just typical A&M students, just average run of the mill.
And of course, all the legislators would roll their eyes.
They knew it was coming on.
But what do you think were, you mentioned his greatest accomplishments.
do you remember any anecdotes, events, frustrations of good humor and or where something went wrong and or of where something went?
Yes.
One that comes to mind is that as his assistant, as I did with Rudder before him at graduation ceremonies, I would present him with a bound soft leather book
that had every movement, every word that was to be spoken at commencement and commissioning exercises.
And I was up on the stage as a commencement got underway.
And he came to me and whispered and said, do you have a?
spare copy of that book you prepared for me for today's program?
I said, are you talking about the commencement program?
I said, you don't have your book?
And he said, well, I went back to the men's room a while ago and I'd put it up on that, he said, you know that tile thing there above the urinals?
And I said, yeah, I know what it is.
He said, I put it up there and went back into the letterman's lounge and missed it and I went back in there and that thing's gone.
I said, I can tell you this, that any other commencement from here on, I will have a spare copy of that, but I don't now.
He said, don't worry about it.
And Haskell, he went through that program.
I think maybe he did better without it than he would have with it, including the introductions.
Now that's how smooth he was.
He was as skillful before an audience as anybody I've ever known in any capacity.
A mother's club was just putty in his hands and poor old General Boatner who was the commandant.
Oh what terrible times we had between the commandant's office and the mother's clubs at one time over a number of issues and he was here then and
Then he went to Koji Prison and broke up the riots over there.
And somebody was talking to him afterwards about how difficult that was.
He says, that was nothing compared to facing an Aggie mother's club.
Koji Prison.
Excuse me.
I deviated.
No.
Dr. Williams and his skills.
I also have the impression that in terms of World War II service record,
accomplishments and so forth were quite comparable to those of Mr.

Rudder but almost no one knew it that's true and he didn't really want to talk about it and he didn't and I don't know that I have ever talked to anyone who ever saw him pull out his medals pull out his uniform or anything I think he thought it was a necessary evil something that he just had to do his best at while he was there and uh
But he would never talk about, you know, if you just mentioned a name to Rutter that sounded like a name that he could recall and he would open up and that was over.
And certainly not in Mr. Rutter's case, you're not inferring and I'm not either, that he was a braggart.
No.
That Rutter was a braggart.
It was just this was part of his life.
What was the typical daily routine?
Compare a typical daily routine in the Rutter family
office years and the Williams office years.
Rudder would get to the office early, and he would have three or four things that he'd laid awake at night worrying about.
And he would come in and tell whoever was at the phone system there to call so-and-so and dean so-and-so in that order.
And he would get that off of his mind.
He'd get somebody working on alternatives to a given problem that was bothering him at that time.
Then he would go into the ladies would come in and have two to three feet deep of papers for him to sign.
And people were always saying, why don't you delegate that?
He said, I want to know where every penny is going.
And if I delegate it, I'll lose track and we'll all get in trouble.
So he refused to sign off administrative things like that.
He expected his staff to organize the incoming mail in order of priority.
And if it was really urgent, we'd show it to him immediately.
If it was a routine urgency, we would draft a response for it.
And most of the time he'd sign it, but he would nearly always put a little note at the bottom so they would know that he knew exactly what was in there and it wasn't just a machine sign-on.
He was one of the best off-the-cuff speakers we ever had.
I'm talking about Rutter.
But if you'd give him a written speech, which he insisted on, he was the world's worst.
He could not follow a written...
speech.
But he would get up at the luncheon before commencement and call the name of every person in the room and their spouse and introduce them to each other.
Remarkable memory about people.
As I told you earlier, I would usually go in every morning while he was signing papers

and bring up subjects and I would quickly try to read his mood and if he was in one of those staring far away looks you just may as well not bring up any topic of controversial nature or something that required serious thought because you were not going to get him off of what was on his mind.
He would nearly always want to have a big lunch with somebody somewhere.
and talk about some business matter.
You're saying almost every day?
Yeah.
He could not rest.
He would come right back.
He put in a full day and time meant nothing to him because that was the operations of the school.
It was all that he really cared about.
Exclusive of family, of course.
But to get in a plane and go to Lubbock and speak to the A&M Club in Lubbock was no big deal.
That's just part of a day.
And then try to find some friends to relax with and tell war stories late at night.
Williams was more private about his feelings.
When did the Williams Day begin?
Williams would spend an hour or two working in his office at home.
Early, early.
Early, early.
That's what I understood.
And he really wouldn't show until around 9 or 9.30.
Because at first I thought, oh boy, that must be nice to not have to come.
I didn't realize he'd been working on mail for two and a half hours.
He was very different about mail
And speech writing, I quickly learned that was a waste of my time because he didn't depend on anyone for his speech material.
He just did it himself and very often wouldn't even have notes.
But he would have a lot of the routine business done on mail and what have you before he ever got the office to spring tapes.
He was more conservative about he was harder to get to see as, let's say, a faculty member or a student or what have you, harder to get to see than Mr. Rutter was.
He would turn down lots of invitations for people to come in and see him and say, well, let so-and-so do that.
He told me early in the game.
that my primary responsibility for him in this job was to be an ombudsman between his office and the student body.
And that's really what he wanted me to do.
He said a similar thing to me with the faculty.
OK.
So he had the two bases there covered.
And he said, there's no need, he said,
You know these guys better than I do, or can get to know them better than I do.
You have more time to do it.
I said, that's what I want you to do.
I want you to help them understand why we're doing things where we are.
Answer all the questions that you possibly can.
If you need to ask me, that's fine.
But do the best you can to keep close to them and let them know they have a friend in this office.
And on that line of thought, about that time we had people like
Roger Miller, Kent Caperton, John Sharp, Gary Morrow, Chad Edwards.
We had quite a few people that we knew.

Talking about what he wanted me to do now, I said, Dr. Williams, I know that some of our student leaders, that we will be able to identify some of them through this work that you have us doing, that are really going to be important.

either in politics or business or education, I said, why don't we set up a program here where once, where when one graduates that we know is really going to be sharpie, that we create a position called, I didn't come right out of that, staff assistant.
whereby we take that person and let him or her work in this office reporting to your assistant on special projects related to student affairs.
And then, when they do go into their life profession, they'll know what it's all about.
